summary: An FBI Special Agent emails colleagues about the discovery of multiple passports belonging to Jeffrey Epstein, including a fraudulent Austrian passport under an alias, and a questionable U.S. Treasury badge/pin found during a search of suitcases. The email includes photo attachments.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The email details the discovery of five U.S. passports and one fraudulent Austrian passport in his possession, found in suitcases.

persons.name: Marius Robert Fortelni
persons.context: This is the name listed on a Republic of Austria passport found in Epstein's possession, with a listed residence in Saudi Arabia and a different date of birth.

persons.name: SA FBI-New York
persons.context: The sender of the email, reporting findings from reviewing suitcases related to the Epstein investigation to colleagues on the Child Exploitation/Human Trafficking Task Force.

connections.description: Epstein possessed a fraudulent Austrian passport issued under the alias Marius Robert Fortelni.

events.title: Discovery of Epstein's Passports and Badge
events.description: An FBI Special Agent reviews suitcases and reports finding five U.S. passports and one fraudulent Austrian passport under an alias for Jeffrey Epstein, along with a questionable U.S. Treasury Customs Service badge/pin.

keyFacts: Five U.S. passports belonging to Jeffrey Epstein were found in suitcases, with expiration dates ranging from the 1970s to 2005.
A fraudulent Republic of Austria passport was found, listing Epstein's alias as 'Marius Robert Fortelni' with a residence in Saudi Arabia and a different date of birth; it expired in 1987.
A U.S. Treasury Customs Service badge or lapel pin, described as possibly a novelty item, was found in an oversized credential wallet with no accompanying credentials.
The findings were documented and photographed by an FBI Special Agent from the Child Exploitation/Human Trafficking Task Force in New York.
